tossups.question: In one tradition, these people are initiated through the kuphotfulwa (“koo-fot-fool-wah”) ceremony in which they drink a sacrificed goat’s blood, ending their status as a thwasa. In 2014, one of these people named Nana Kwaku Bonsam claimed to have predicted Cristiano Ronaldo’s injury. Some of these people perform ancestral prayers before suggesting various forms of muti (“MOO-tee”). A state office regulates examples of these people called babus in (*) Tanzania. Inyangas and sangomas are varieties of these people found among the Shona and Zulu. They have been partly blamed for the pervasive murder of albinos near Lake Victoria, as these people use their body parts in remedies. For 10 points, name these religious figures from many traditional African religions who use herbs or magic to cure disease.
tossups.answer: witch doctors [or medicine men or traditional healers or shamans; accept babus until read; accept juju priests or fetish priests or soothsayers; prompt on sorcerers or magicians or witches or herbalists or priests or holy men] <WA, Religion>
tossups.answer_formatted: witch doctors <WA, Religion> [or medicine men or traditional healers or shamans; accept babus until read; accept juju priests or fetish priests or soothsayers; prompt on sorcerers or magicians or witches or herbalists or priests or holy men]

tossups.question: Alfred Kroeber claimed that this story was intended to “symbolize into complete mystification,” a line included in the author’s lecture “Biography of a Story.” That lecture is cited in a 2013 article by Ruth Franklin about the “torrent of letters” that were mailed in response to this story’s publication. An old man in this story claims that a “pack of young fools” will “go back to living in caves” for trying to get rid of an occurrence that used to mean (*) “corn be heavy soon.” In this story, which was published in the June 26th, 1948, issue of The New Yorker, a woman screams “It isn’t fair, it isn’t right” after Mr. Summers instructs “Let’s finish quickly” when a paper with a black spot falls out of that woman’s hand. For 10 points, Tessie Hutchinson is stoned to death at the end of what story by Shirley Jackson?
tossups.answer: “The Lottery” <ML, Short Fiction>
tossups.answer_formatted: “The Lottery” <ML, Short Fiction>

tossups.question: The Wooster Group’s play The B-Side is inspired by Bruce Jackson’s work documenting the folklore of these locations in Texas. Jim Marshall photographed a country singer giving the middle finger during a concert at one of these places. The song “Midnight Special” was recorded by a musician nicknamed “Lead Belly” during John and Alan Lomax’s studies at one of these locations in Louisiana. A song titled for one of these places begins “I hear the (*) train a comin’ / It’s rolling round the bend.” A 1957 rock hit mentions how “The band was jumpin’ and the joint began to swing” in one of these places. A song about the “Blues” of one of these places in Folsom titles a hit by Johnny Cash. For 10 points, an Elvis Presley hit is about the “rock” played in what sort of place when the warden throws a party?
tossups.answer: prisons [or jails or jailhouses; accept Folsom Prison Blues or Jailhouse Rock or Negro Folklore from Texas State Prisons] <RK, Other Arts: Music>
tossups.answer_formatted: prisons <RK, Other Arts: Music> [or jails or jailhouses; accept Folsom Prison Blues or Jailhouse Rock or Negro Folklore from Texas State Prisons]
acceptable: Negro Folklore from Texas State Prisons

tossups.question: Deviations from this law can be modeled by the use of a deformed exponential function named for Aquilanti and Mundim. Ronnie Bell modified this equation by introducing a quantity, Q, which is a function of particle mass, barrier height, and barrier width, in order to account for tunneling. This equation is used to predict the shelf-life of drugs. This equation includes a term based on the frequency of (*) collisions and the complexity of the orientations required to reach the transition state. According to this equation, plotting the inverse of temperature against the log of the rate constant results in a straight line whose slope is proportional to the activation energy. For 10 points, name this equation that predicts reaction rates based on temperature.
tossups.answer: Arrhenius equation <RN, Chemistry>
tossups.answer_formatted: Arrhenius equation <RN, Chemistry>

tossups.question: An essay by this philosopher contrasts the “bland and urbane” attitude of Socrates towards unbelievers with another group’s “vindictive fury” in discussing the “Moral Problem” of the title sort of person. In that essay, this philosopher discusses John Stuart Mill’s rejection of the question “who made me?” to rebut the “first cause” argument. He’s not Karl Popper, but this man illustrated how the burden of proof is on unfalsifiable claims by imagining an (*) object too small to be seen by telescopes. This philosopher gave a talk at the National Secular Society on why he thought that the “best and wisest of men” was not Christ, titled “Why I am Not a Christian.” A “teapot” thought experiment is named after, for 10 points, what philosopher who, along with Alfred North Whitehead, wrote Principia Mathematica?
tossups.answer: Bertrand Russell [or Bertrand Arthur William Russell; accept Russell’s teapot] <ML, Phil/Thought>
tossups.answer_formatted: Bertrand Russell <ML, Phil/Thought> [or Bertrand Arthur William Russell; accept Russell’s teapot]

tossups.question: In a novel titled for one of these animals, the protagonist claims that “prime numbers are like life,” explaining why they are used to number the book’s chapters. In that novel, the socially-awkward protagonist discovers letters revealing that his mother is alive while investigating the death of one of these animals by pitchfork. In another novel, one of these animals causes the death of the psychotic murderer Selden, who had received signals from his brother-in-law Barrymore while living in the (*) moors. It’s not a horse, but a quote about one of these animals from “The Adventure of Silver Blaze” titles a Mark Haddon novel. In another novel, the protagonist discovers that Jack Stapleton painted one of these animals in phosphorus in hopes of reclaiming an estate. For 10 points, Sherlock Holmes investigates what sort of animal that terrorizes Baskerville Hall?
tossups.answer: dogs [or hounds; or The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time; or The Hound of Baskervilles] <RK, Long Fiction>
tossups.answer_formatted: dogs <RK, Long Fiction> [or hounds; or The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time; or The Hound of Baskervilles]
acceptable: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time

tossups.question: Charles Frederick Worth designed the “Electric Light” dress for the matriarch of this family to wear at an 1883 ball. Another member of this family who renamed P. T. Barnum’s “Great Roman Hippodrome” to Madison Square Garden controversially exclaimed “the public be damned” in a newspaper interview. A third member of this family was the most prominent financial backer of William Walker’s invasion of (*) Nicaragua, but then withdrew his support, leading to Walker’s overthrow. Richard Morris Hunt designed the estates of The Breakers and Biltmore for this family, which was brought to prominence by the founder of the New York Central Railroad, who built a great transport empire. For 10 points, give this surname of the shipping magnate Cornelius, who was nicknamed “Commodore.”
tossups.answer: Vanderbilt family <RK, US History>
tossups.answer_formatted: Vanderbilt family <RK, US History>

tossups.question: Marina Costa-Jackson starred in a performance of this opera that kicked off the LA Opera’s 2019–2020 season. This opera titles the signature song of Charles Aznavour (“sharl ahz-nah-VOOR”). In this opera, a character claims that an English Lord hired him to play his violin until a neighbor’s annoying parrot died. Three descending chords open a moonlit love duet near the end of this opera’s first act. In this opera, the wealthy (*) Alcindoro (“all-cheen-DOH-roh”) leads a woman into a café, where she sings a triple-time aria also known as her “waltz,” titled “Quando me’n vo.” In this opera, which was adapted into the musical Rent, Musetta tries to win back her boyfriend Marcello. The love between Rodolfo and Mimì is central to, for 10 points, what opera by Giacomo Puccini about the Parisian artistic life?
tossups.answer: La bohème <WA, Classical/Opera>
tossups.answer_formatted: La bohème <WA, Classical/Opera>

tossups.question: This process is facilitated by Tyrode’s albumin lactate pyruvate medium or Sydney medium. One participant in this process expresses the CatSper calcium channel. This process relies on the interaction between CD9 and Izumo. The tripeptide FPP is used to activate one participant in this process via capacitation. During this process, cortical granules are exocytosed and their hydrolytic enzymes modify the (*) zona pellucida in response to a calcium wave. Prior to this process, one participant in this process is initially arrested at metaphase II, and after this process, it ejects a polar body before implantation. This process typically occurs in the fallopian tube. For 10 points, name this process in which an egg and sperm fuse to form a zygote.
tossups.answer: fertilization [or word forms; accept IVF or in vitro fertilization; prompt on conception or word forms] <EM, Biology: Dev/Plant>
tossups.answer_formatted: fertilization <EM, Biology: Dev/Plant> [or word forms; accept IVF or in vitro fertilization; prompt on conception or word forms]

tossups.question: The mistress of a ruler of this name was an Irish-born Spanish dancer who became famous for performing the provocative “Spider Dance.” That ruler of this name collected portraits of women in his “Gallery of Beauties,” one of which depicted his mistress Lola Montez. Otto, the son of a ruler of this name, became the first king of Greece. A ruler of this name commissioned a building designed by architect Eduard Reidel (“RIDE-ul”) with a bridal chamber inspired by (*) Lohengrin (“LOH-un-grin”). That last independent ruler of the Wittelsbach (“VIT-uls-bock”) dynasty, who had this name, settled Richard Wagner’s (“VOG-nur’s”) debts and patronized much of his late work. A ruler of this name built a fairy-tale-inspired castle at Neuschwanstein (“NOYSH-von-shtyne”). For 10 points, give this name, shared by two 19th-century Bavarian rulers, including a “Mad King.”
tossups.answer: Ludwig [or Louis; accept Ludwig I or Ludwig II; accept Ludwig der Marchenkonig or Ludwig the Mad King] <ML, European History>
tossups.answer_formatted: Ludwig <ML, European History> [or Louis; accept Ludwig I or Ludwig II; accept Ludwig der Marchenkonig or Ludwig the Mad King]

tossups.question: A poet from this movement described the “timid little feet of clay” of “dusky, half-clad” prostitutes going from “street to street.” The speaker of a poem from this movement nearly drowns in a river and jumps from a building before declaring “Fine as wine! Life is fine!” A poet from this movement imagined “hogs / Hunted and penned in an inglorious spot” in a poem that asserts, “Like men we’ll face the murderous, cowardly pack,” titled (*) “If We Must Die.” Another poet from this movement described a man who sleeps “like a rock or a man that’s dead” after playing a “sad raggy tune like a musical fool… Down on Lenox Avenue.” The italicized line “Or does it explode?” ends a poem from this movement that ponders, “What happens to a dream deferred?” For 10 points, Claude McKay and Langston Hughes belonged to what 1920s “Renaissance”?
tossups.answer: Harlem Renaissance (The first poem is “Harlem Shadows.”) <NC, Poetry>
tossups.answer_formatted: Harlem Renaissance <NC, Poetry>

tossups.question: Engineering historian Donald Hill translated a book in this language that includes depictions of double suction-pump valves. A book of advice for making “trick vessels” was written in this language by one of three brothers who were all inventors. Supposedly, books began to be mass-produced in this language after soldiers learned the secrets of printing from Chinese captives taken at the Battle of the (*) Talas River. Medical writers in this language, such as Rhazes (“RA-zeez”), took advantage of a massive effort to translate works from Greek into this language in the 8th and 9th centuries, primarily at the House of Wisdom. For 10 points, name this main language used by the physician Avicenna and scholars sponsored by Caliph Ma’mun.
tossups.answer: Arabic [or al-arabiyyah] <WA, World History>
tossups.answer_formatted: Arabic <WA, World History> [or al-arabiyyah]

tossups.question: A painting in which an angel holds this man’s hand as he writes in a book was reworked into a similar scene, in which this man rests his knee on a stool and hastily scribbles as he listens to an overhead angel. A room that Jacques Cobaert (“zhahk ko-BART”) never decorated holds a painting by the same artist titled for this figure in which an angel swoops in from the right towards an executioner, who holds a sword and is about to behead him. The artist’s earlier painting (*) The Cardsharps provided the basis for secondary figures in a tenebrist painting titled for this man in the Contarelli Chapel. In that painting, this figure may be an old man or a youth counting coins, both of whom are highlighted by a diagonal beam of light that is parallel to the pointing arm of Jesus. For 10 points, the “calling” of what saint was depicted by Caravaggio?
tossups.answer: Saint Matthew [accept The Calling of Saint Matthew or Vocazione di San Matteo] <AR, Painting/Sculpture>
tossups.answer_formatted: Saint Matthew <AR, Painting/Sculpture> [accept The Calling of Saint Matthew or Vocazione di San Matteo]

tossups.question: A passage from the Iliad describes how this man’s son Isander was slain by Ares, and how he “devoured his own soul” wandering the Plain of Aleion. In that “unequal exchange” episode from Book VI, Diomedes puts his spear away because his ancestor, Oeneus (“EE-nee-us”), was a friend of this character. The legend of Potiphar’s wife mirrors a story in which this figure was falsely accused of rape by the lustful wife of Proitos, (*) Stheneboea (“sthen-uh-BEE-uh”). This hero’s most famous companion was a brother of Chrysaor (“cry-SAY-or”) who helped him in a quest in which he shoved lead (“led”) down a creature’s throat. Later, this man tried to fly to Olympus, but fell off his mount when he was stung by a gadfly. For 10 points, name this hero who rode Pegasus to slay the Chimera.
tossups.answer: Bellerophontes <AR, Myths/Legends>
tossups.answer_formatted: Bellerophontes <AR, Myths/Legends>

tossups.question: This company’s Corporate Design Program was led by Eliot Noyes (“noise”), who hired Charles and Ray Eames to create a film presented at the 1964 World’s Fair in an egg-shaped pavilion designed by Eero Saarinen (“arrow SAH-ree-nen”). Fred Brooks’ book The Mythical Man-Month recounts the harm done by adding workers to this firm’s overdue and over-budget System/360 line of products. This firm, which grew out of Charles Flint’s Computing Tabulating Recording Company, made the largest software (*) acquisition in history in 2018 after spending 34 billion dollars to acquire Red Hat Linux. Its early profits came from machines for processing punch cards. This firm made the first “personal computer,” and its nickname is “Big Blue.” For 10 points, name this firm founded by Thomas Watson, who names its Jeopardy-playing robot.
tossups.answer: IBM [or International Business Machines; prompt on Big Blue until read] <RK, Other Academic>
tossups.answer_formatted: IBM <RK, Other Academic> [or International Business Machines; prompt on Big Blue until read]

tossups.question: Separate domains of knowledge for this faculty, as well as the “societal” and the “psychological,” were identified by Elliot Turiel. Studies that classify this faculty using such “orientations” as “social-contract” and “instrumental-relativist” are rejected by a feminist approach based on “care.” This faculty arises from “social intuitionism” according to a theory that explains political differences through differences in this faculty’s “foundations,” promoted by NYU professor (*) Jonathan Haidt (“height”). A thought experiment about Heinz stealing medicine to save his wife was used to illustrate this faculty’s development in pre-conventional, conventional, and post-conventional stages. For 10 points, Lawrence Kohlberg proposed a six-stage model of what faculty, which determines right from wrong?
tossups.answer: morality [or moral development; or morals; prompt on ethics of care] <RK, Social Science: Psych>
tossups.answer_formatted: morality <RK, Social Science: Psych> [or moral development; or morals; prompt on ethics of care]

tossups.question: The nth eigenfunction given by the heat equation with Dirichlet (“DEE-ree-klet”) boundary conditions is this function of n, times a constant, times x over L. The union of “this function of one-over-x” and the origin is used to construct a space that is connected but not path-connected; that space is called the “topologist’s curve” of this function. In complex analysis, this function is defined as e-to-the-i-z minus e-to-the-negative-i-z, all over 2i. Like tangent, this function can be (*) approximated by the line y-equals-x for small values of x, according to the small-angle approximation. This function appears in the Fourier expansion of odd functions. The inverse of this function is the antiderivative of one over the square-root of “one minus x-squared.” For 10 points, name this trigonometric function whose derivative is cosine.
tossups.answer: sine [or sin; accept sine of x, with any letter in place of x, such as theta; do not accept or prompt on “sinh” or “hyperbolic sine”] <NC, Math>
tossups.answer_formatted: sine <NC, Math> [or sin; accept sine of x, with any letter in place of x, such as theta; do not accept or prompt on "sinh" or "hyperbolic sine"]
acceptable: sine of x, with any letter

tossups.question: This author burned the manuscript of the redemptive second volume of one of his novels shortly before dying of self-starvation. A play by this author ends with a “silent scene” in which a postmaster stands “like a question mark” and a pair of similarly-named squires gesticulate furiously at each other. This author ended a novel’s first part by addressing his country as “O Rus’ (“roose”)” and comparing its “headlong motion” to a three-horse carriage or troika. In a play by this author, cronies of a corrupt (*) mayor offer bribes to a man who they mistake for the title incognito (“in-cog-NEET-oh”) bureaucrat. This author of The Inspector-General created a trickster who gambles with Nozdryov (“NOZZ-dree-off”) while travelling the countryside to collect the title items in a scheme to sell deceased peasants for money. For 10 points, name this Russian author who created Chichikov in his novel Dead Souls.
tossups.answer: Nikolai Gogol [or Nikolai Vasilievich Gogol] <WA, Misc Lit>
tossups.answer_formatted: Nikolai Gogol <WA, Misc Lit> [or Nikolai Vasilievich Gogol]

tossups.question: One property of these particles is explained by the idea of one eigenvalue of a two-by-two matrix increasing if the other decreases. The DONUT collaboration searched for one of these particles by using protons accelerated by the Tevatron to measure the decay of charged mesons. The observation of a process that [emphasize] does not generate these particles would suggest that they could serve as their own antiparticles, a property named for (*) Majorana (“ma-yo-RA-na”). The finding that these particles emitted by the Sun experience oscillations among their three flavors provided evidence that they have non-zero mass. A neutron becomes a proton, a positron, and one of these particles in beta-plus decay. For 10 points, name these small fermions with neutral charge.
tossups.answer: neutrinos [accept electron neutrinos; prompt on fermions] <RN, Physics>
tossups.answer_formatted: neutrinos <RN, Physics> [accept electron neutrinos; prompt on fermions]

tossups.question: John Moses wrote a book about the “Controversy” surrounding the theories on the origins of this war by German historian Fritz Fischer. Christopher Clark is best known for a history of the run-up to this war titled The Sleepwalkers. A. J. P. Taylor proposed the “Railway Thesis” of this war’s origins in his book War by Timetable, in which he argued that this war could not be stopped after (*) mobilization began. Willy–Nicky letters were exchanged in the run-up to this war, whose origins were chronicled by Barbara Tuchman in The Guns of August. “November criminals” were blamed for defeat in this war by the “stab-in-the-back legend,” which fueled the growth of anti-Semitism under the Weimar Republic. For 10 points, name this war that began with the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand.
tossups.answer: World War I [or the Great War or War to End All Wars] <ML, Historiography>  If the game is tied at this point, report to your tournament director for tiebreaker instructions.   Bonuses
tossups.answer_formatted: World War I <ML, Historiography> If the game is tied at this point, report to your tournament director for tiebreaker instructions. Bonuses [or the Great War or War to End All Wars]
acceptable: World War I <ML, Historiography>  If the game is tied at this point, report to your tournament director for tiebreaker instructions.   Bonuses
World War I <ML, Historiography>  If the game is tied at this point, report to your tournament director for tiebreaker instructions.   Bonuses

bonuses.leadin: The 1992 Mabo case overturned the previous assumption that land occupied by Aborigines had this status, and therefore granted them land rights unless the Crown had explicitly given away the land. For 10 points each:
answers: Egypt AND Sudan [accept Misr in place of “Egypt”; do not accept or prompt on “South Sudan”] <WA, Geography>
parts: Give this Latin term that refers to land that, by law, is uninhabited or unoccupied.
Most of this continent’s region of Marie Byrd Land is terra nullius that has not been claimed by any sovereign nation. The underground Lake Vostok is on this continent.

A tract of land called Bir Tawil, which is found on the border of these two countries, is terra nullius that is claimed by neither. The Hala’ib Triangle is also disputed by these two African countries.
answers_formatted: Egypt AND Sudan <WA, Geography> [accept Misr in place of “Egypt; do not accept or prompt on "South Sudan"]

bonuses.leadin: A cycle of murals by this artist consists of 10 panels, including “Instruments of Power,” which depicts trains and zeppelins. For 10 points each:
answers: Thomas Hart Benton (The painting is Achelous and Hercules.)
parts: Name this artist who created the America Today mural during the early stages of the Great Depression. Another of this artist’s paintings recasts a classical myth of a hero wrestling a bull in a rural American setting.
Benton is associated with this school of American painting that also included John Steuart Curry. Its most famous member, Grant Wood, depicted a dentist holding a pitchfork in American Gothic.
Blue Poles and Lavender Mist are works by this student of Thomas Hart Benton, whose “action painting” included dripping paint on canvas to make his Abstract Expressionist works.
metadata: The painting is Achelous and Hercules.

bonuses.leadin: This action titles a love poem whose speaker claims “everything carries me to you, / as if everything that exists… were little boats / that sail / toward those isles of yours that wait for me.” For 10 points each:
answers: saddest [accept “Tonight I Can Write the Saddest Lines” or “Puedo escribir los versos más tristes esta noche”; prompt on sad or triste]
parts: Name this action. A line from W. S. Merwin’s translation of a certain poem states that “love is so short” while this action “is so long.”

The poet attributes this quality to the line “Love is so short, forgetting is so long.” The poet writes “The night is starry and the stars are blue and shiver in the distance” after promising to write lines of poetry with this quality.
This Chilean poet of “If You Forget Me” included “Tonight I Can Write the Saddest Lines” in his Twenty Love Poems and a Song of Despair.
answers_formatted: saddest [accept Tonight I Can Write the Saddest Lines or Puedo escribir los versos más tristes esta noche; prompt on sad or triste]
acceptable: Tonight I Can Write the Saddest Lines
Puedo escribir los versos más tristes esta noche

bonuses.leadin: Coventry (“KAW-vin-tree”) Patmore’s poem “The Angel in the House” epitomizes this era’s ideal of submissive womanhood, stating “Man must be pleased; but him to please / Is woman’s pleasure.” For 10 points each:
answers: domesticity [accept Cult of Domesticity; do not accept or prompt on other answers]
spheres [accept public sphere or private sphere] <WA, Historiography>
parts: Name this historical era that lasted from 1837 to 1901, spanning the reign of its namesake queen.

Historians often refer to the Victorian middle-class ideal of the pious wife who stayed at home as the “cult of” this specific word. Barbara Welter called the same notion the “Cult of True Womanhood.”

Another concept from women’s historiography is the doctrine of “separate” examples of realms known by this term, with women having dominion in the “private” one of them. Much of Jürgen Habermas’s (“YUR-gun HAH-bur-moss’s”) work concerns the “public” place known by this term, referring to where political and social discourse takes place.
answers_formatted: domesticity [accept Cult of Domesticity; do not accept or prompt on "other answers"]

bonuses.leadin: Sophocles’ play The Women of Trachis ends with the death of this man after his wife sends him a poisoned shirt. For 10 points each:
answers: Seneca the Younger [or Lucius Annaeus Seneca]
parts: Name this character who, in a Euripides play about his “madness,” murders his family after bringing Cerberus from the underworld for his twelfth labor.

Euripides’ play The Madness of Heracles inspired this later author’s play The Mad Hercules, which is among his ten blood-thirsty tragedies. Another of those tragedies by this non-French author is Phaedra.

Euripides submitted Alcestis to the Dionysia in place of one of these works, which often centered on Heracles. This dramatic genre, which is named for the raucous creatures that featured in it, was the third most popular genre of ancient theatre after tragedy and comedy.

bonuses.leadin: Because he had poor eyesight, one member of this body frequently asked his colleagues to describe what was happening in pornographic films that they had to watch in order to determine whether to allow them on the market. For 10 points each:
answers: Supreme Court of the United States [or SCOTUS]
parts: Name this body that used a rule asking whether a film or book had “redeeming social importance” to evaluate whether it was obscene.

In a case named for Nico Jacobellis, a theater operator from this state, Potter Stewart put forth his “I know it when I see it” description of pornography. Dollree Mapp was arrested for possession of pornography in another case originating from this state.

As a postal inspector and the head of the Society for the Suppression of Vice, this man was a leader in the movement to censor books that he deemed “obscene.” His actions also targeted birth control providers such as Margaret Sanger.
acceptable: Supreme Court of the United States
Supreme Court of the United States

bonuses.leadin: A reduction in the amount of this substance on Earth can drive a positive feedback loop in which less solar radiation is reflected, causing the temperature to rise, causing the amount of this substance to drop again, and so on. For 10 points each:
answers: ice [accept sea ice or pack ice]
parts: Name this substance. Large amounts of it can agglomerate into “pack” types that impede ship movement.

These objects name a hypothetical event in which most of the Earth’s surface was frozen about 650 million years ago, which is thought to have resulted from an extreme reversed form of the ice–albedo feedback loop.
This term collectively designates all of the Earth’s frozen water. The area that it designates would have greatly expanded during the Snowball Earth scenario.

bonuses.leadin: So-called “induced,” “latent,” and “pent-up” examples of this quantity are often said to be “activated” by changes in the availability. For 10 points each:
answers: traffic [or congestion; accept road traffic or network traffic]
parts: Name this quantity. Functions for this quantity are typically downward-sloping, with the exception of situations named for Sir Robert Giffen, and are described by the Slutsky equation.
In economics, the most commonly studied type of induced demand is the increase in this phenomenon that can result from added capacity; examples of such increases include Braess’s (“brass’s”) paradox.

The “price” of traffic can be thought of as consisting of both monetary costs, via extra fuel wasted, and this other sort of cost, which refers to the most valuable alternative choice that a consumer could have made with their time and money had they not been in traffic.

bonuses.leadin: Name these non-European nations with eccentric Neo-Nazi movements, for 10 points each.
answers: South Africa [or Republic of South Africa] <WA, Other Academic>
parts: Miguel Serrano, a diplomat from this country, claimed that Hitler will return from Antarctica as an “avatar” to lead humanity against the Hyperboreans. In 2000, a world Neo-Nazi rally took place in its capital of Santiago.

Neo-Nazi movements in this nation, such as Gal Undesten or “Fire Nation,” trade in extreme ethnic prejudice against Chinese people. This country’s president, Battulga Khaltmaa (“BOT-too-lug HALT-mah”), has been embattled in a constitutional crisis since March 2019.
A leader of this country’s Neo-Nazi movement, Eugène Terre’Blanche (“oo-ZHEN tair-BLONSH”), was beaten to death with a panga or machete while asleep in 2010.
answers_formatted: South Africa <WA, Other Academic> [or Republic of South Africa]

bonuses.leadin: Studying these substances is the most important application of magnetohydrodynamics, also known as MHD. For 10 points each:
answers: Reynolds number [accept magnetic Reynolds number; prompt on Re]
parts: Name this so-called “fourth state of matter,” a type of highly ionized gas that comprises most matter in stars.

In MHD, the product of the plasma’s velocity and length scales divided by magnetic diffusivity is a dimensionless parameter often called the “magnetic” version of this quantity, which is the ratio of inertial to viscous forces.

MHD describes these low-frequency oscillations that propagate in a direction parallel to the magnetic field lines. Heat transfer via these phenomena explains why the Sun’s corona is hotter than its surface.

bonuses.leadin: In this country, Operation Pegasus took place after an evacuation from Arnhem Bridge. For 10 points each:
answers: Netherlands [or Nederlands or Holland or Dutch]
beggars [or geuzen or gueux; accept Sea Beggars or Watergeuzen] <ML, European History>
parts: Name this country ruled by Queen Wilhelmina during World War II. This country surrendered in World War II after a German invasion took Rotterdam.
The Netherlands were the site of this failed operation in 1944, which had the goal of seizing bridges to attempt to invade Germany. This operation was the largest airborne assault in history.

A Dutch resistance group during World War II named itself after this occupation. Their name refers to an earlier group of nobles who fought the Spanish during the Eighty Years’ War, who also named themselves after this occupation.
answers_formatted: beggars <ML, European History> [or geuzen or gueux; accept Sea Beggars or Watergeuzen]

bonuses.leadin: A poem titled for this city notes “I always like the summer” because you can “be warm / all the time / not only when you go to bed / and sleep” and was written by Nikki Giovanni, who grew up in this city. For 10 points each:
answers: Knoxville, Tennessee (The unnamed work is James Agee’s “Knoxville: Summer of 1915.”)
Alex Haley [or Alexander Murray Palmer Haley]
Cormac McCarthy [or Charles McCarthy] <RK, Misc Lit>
parts: Name this city whose summer is also the subject of a prose piece that was written in 90 minutes and became the prologue to the author’s tragic autobiographical novel A Death in the Family.
Knoxville contains a Heritage Square dedicated to this author, who extended one of his many interviews for Playboy into the book The Autobiography of Malcolm X.
Though he grew up in Knoxville, this author later moved to Texas, whose landscape inspired him to pen Westerns like Blood Meridian and No Country for Old Men.
metadata: The unnamed work is James Agee’s “Knoxville: Summer of 1915.”

bonuses.leadin: The forger Mark Hofmann managed to sell a fake copy of a transcript of part of these documents, the Anthon Transcript, for 25,000 dollars. For 10 points each:
answers: the golden plates [prompt on plates; do not accept or prompt on “golden tablets”]
parts: Name these documents that are believed to have been written in Reformed Egyptian, the language used by Nephi, son of Lehi the prophet. They were supposedly found near Manchester, New York, in 1822.
This prophet founded the Latter Day Saints church after finding those golden plates.

This Mormon leader received a vision from the “Plates of Laban,” after which he proclaimed himself King James I. He established a community at Beaver Island, Wisconsin, after losing a succession struggle following Joseph Smith’s death.
answers_formatted: the golden plates [prompt on plates; do not accept or prompt on "golden tablets"]

bonuses.leadin: The first complete recording of this collection was made in the 1930s by Edwin Fischer and is still regarded as one of the best. For 10 points each:
answers: The Well-Tempered Clavier [or Das Wohltemperierte Klavier; prompt on The Well-Tuned Piano]
parts: Name this collection whose title is referenced in the second studio album by synthesizer player Wendy Carlos. A wavering 6-hour minimalist magnum opus is titled after this collection of preludes and fugues in all 24 keys.

This minimalist composer used just intonation in The Well-Tuned Piano, titled in reference to Bach. His suite Compositions 1960 calls for releasing a butterfly into the concert hall and waiting until it stops flapping.
This minimalist wrote the piano pieces Music of Changes and 4'33" (“four minutes and thirty-three seconds”), in which the performer simply sits there for the title length of time.
answers_formatted: The Well-Tempered Clavier [or Das Wohltemperierte Klavier; prompt on The Well-Tuned Piano]

bonuses.leadin: The name ekadanta (“ay-kuh-DAHN-tuh”), which means “one tooth,” derives from a deformity in this physical feature. For 10 points each:
answers: Ganesha’s elephant head [accept answers indicating the elephant head of Ganesh; accept alternative names for Ganesh such as Ganapati or Vinayaka or Pillaiyar; prompt on head or elephant head or Ganesh’s head]
Shiva [accept Eshwar or Neelakantha or Nataraja]
parts: Identify this physical feature of Parvati’s elder son, which was gained after he was killed by his father. In a different myth, this physical feature was acquired when Lord Shani looked at a baby.
Ganesha’s father is this Hindu destroyer god, who comprises the Trimurti with Vishnu and Brahma. The Ganges River emerges from his matted hair.

Ganesha’s broken tusk legendarily resulted from an incident in which an avatar of Vishnu attacked him with a parashu, which is one of these objects. In the Odyssey, a disguised Odysseus shoots an arrow through twelve of these objects in front of Penelope’s suitors.
answers_formatted: Ganesha’s elephant head [accept answers indicating the elephant head of Ganesh; accept alternative names for Ganesh such as Ganapati or Vinayaka or Pillaiyar; prompt on head or elephant head or Ganesh’s head]
acceptable: answers indicating the elephant head of Ganesh
alternative names for Ganesh such as Ganapati

bonuses.leadin: Women called snaars were lower class citizens in this city, where residents declared allegiance by giving the Short Declaration. For 10 points each:
answers: Batavia [accept Batavia massacre; prompt on Jakarta]
Netherlands [or Nederlands or Holland or Dutch]
pirate [accept raider or equivalents; prompt on shipbuilders] <ML, World History>
parts: Name this setting of a massacre of Chinese citizens in 1740. This city was built on land captured from the Banten (“BAHN-tun”) Sultanate.
Batavia was a colony owned by this country’s East India Company, which was known as the VOC. This country colonized Indonesia.
The Dutch East India Company created Fort Zeelandia, which was famously besieged by a member of this profession. Moro people in the Sulu Sea frequently had this occupation.
answers_formatted: pirate <ML, World History> [accept raider or equivalents; prompt on shipbuilders]

bonuses.leadin: Standard techniques from this country’s dance styles include the “gold standard crown,” in which the dancer swings their leg backwards and holds it steady over their head. For 10 points each:
answers: China [or People’s Republic of China; or PRC; or Zhōnghuá Rénmín Gònghéguó]
model operas [or yàngbǎnxì; accept Eight Model Operas; prompt on revolutionary operas until read] <JZ, Other Arts: Dance>
parts: Name this country whose highly varied dance forms reflect its 56 different recognized minority groups, including the Uyghurs (“wee-gurs”) of its western regions.
This propagandistic dance company based in New York City, founded by Falun Gong followers, promotes itself as reviving “5,000 years of Chinese culture” through dance.

Propagandistic dances feature in the Chinese operas known by this term, which were selected by Mao Zedong’s wife Jiang Qing (“jyong ching”) for their portrayal of revolutionary struggles. The fact that there were only eight of these operas gave rise to the quip “Eight hundred million people watched eight shows.”
answers_formatted: China [or People’s Republic of China; or PRC; or Zhōnghuá Rénmín Gònghéguó]
model operas <JZ, Other Arts: Dance> [or yàngbǎnxì; accept Eight Model Operas; prompt on revolutionary operas until read]

bonuses.leadin: MNIST, a database of 70,000 images of handwritten digits, is often used to train these algorithms. For 10 points each:
answers: neural networks [or artificial neural networks; or neural nets; or connectionist systems; prompt on networks or NNs or ANNs]
backpropagation [or backprop; or backwards propagation of errors; prompt on gradient descent]
parts: Name these algorithms used in machine learning that may consist of weighted edges between input, hidden, and output layers. Early examples of them include perceptrons.

This type of iterative algorithm used to train neural networks calculates the gradient of the error or loss function of the network’s output, then uses those computations to calculate the gradient for the previous layers, and so on, updating the network’s weights.
Backpropagation uses this rule from calculus, which gives the derivative of “f of g-of-x” as “f-prime of g-of-x, times g-prime of x.”
answers_formatted: neural networks [or artificial neural networks; or neural nets; or connectionist systems; prompt on networks or NNs or ANNs]
backpropagation [or backprop; or backwards propagation of errors; prompt on gradient descent]

bonuses.leadin: A poem by an author of this ethnicity asks “what is this thing called aroha?” before an interlocutor responds “like, I’m euchred (“YOO-kurd”), man, I’m eclipsed.” For 10 points each:
answers: Māori [do not accept or prompt on “New Zealander”] (The lead-in refers to Hone Tuwhare’s poem “Hotere.”)
Malouf [accept David Malouf or Amin Maalouf] <JM, Long Fiction>
parts: Name this ethnicity whose culture is explored in Kerri Hulme’s Booker-winning novel The Bone People, in which two people who are partially of this ethnicity raise a mute white child.

This country’s indigenous people are the subject of novels like The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith, written by Thomas Keneally (“kuh-NEEL-ee”). This country is home to the novelists Miles Franklin and Patrick White.

An author with this surname wrote about Gemmy Fairley, who is raised by Aborigines before trying to reintegrate into European society, in the novel Remembering Babylon. A French-Lebanese author with a similarly spelled surname wrote Samarkand and The Rock of Tanios.
answers_formatted: Māori [do not accept or prompt on "New Zealander"]
metadata: The lead-in refers to Hone Tuwhare’s poem “Hotere.”

bonuses.leadin: The regulatory variety of these cells express the Foxp3 transcription factor, which is mutated in IPEX syndrome. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this type of lymphocyte. The “helper” variety of these cells expresses CD4 and are diminished by HIV infection.
T cells mature in this organ found in the chest, where self-reactive cells are deleted. Tumors of this organ can sometimes cause aplastic anemia and often occur in patients with myasthenia gravis.

T cells express PD-1, whose interaction with PD-L1 serves as one of these regulatory steps in T cell activation. Inhibitors of these steps, like ipilimumab (“ip-uh-LIM-oo-mab”) and nivolumab (“niv-OH-loo-mab”), are used to treat cancer.
